facts.text: Present President entered upon office on May 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Under Art. 56 of the Constitution the President holds office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office. The present incumbent of the high office entered upon his office on May 12, 1952, and, as already stated, his term is due to expire on the mid-night of May 12, 1957.

issues.text: whether there is anything in the Constitution indicating the time at which and the manner in which such doubts and disputes have to be inquired into and decided

anchor.surface_text: Article 71 1 Undoubtedly confers jurisdiction and power on this Court to inquire into and decide all doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of President or Vice-President and this Court will have to inquire into and decide the same. But the question is whether there is anything in the Constitution indicating the time

issues.text: What is the meaning to be given to the word election as used in Art. 71(1)

anchor.surface_text: We need approach the construction of Art. 71 in the light of the decision of this Court. issues.text: whether the electoral college is to consist of those members falling under clauses (a) and (b), who are elected at the crucial date... or must be constituted after the elections in all States and Union territories are completed

anchor.surface_text: For ascertaining how such election of President is to be held, we have to go back to Art. 54, which runs thus The President shall be elected by the members of an electoral college consisting of- a the elected members of both Houses of Parliament and b the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States. On one side it is said that the electoral college is to consist of those members falling under clauses a and b , who are elected at the crucial date, that is to say, the date when the election is to take place.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand it is contended that the electoral college must be constituted after the elections in all States and Union territories are completed and should consist of all the elected members falling within both the categories. Inasmuch as elections have not taken place at all in Himachal Pradesh and in two constituencies of the State of Punjab, the electoral college cannot be constituted until after those members are also elected.

arguments.claim: Under Art. 71, Court bound to inquire and decide any doubt or dispute as soon as raised by citizen regardless of foundation

anchor.surface_text: Both the petitioners share the same view and contend that a grave doubt has arisen in connection with the election of the President and that such a doubt must, under Art. 71, be inquired into and decided by this Court. The extreme contention put forward on behalf of the petitioners is that it does not matter whether the doubt is well founded or not or whether it is good, bad or indifferent this Court is bound to inquire into and decide the same as soon as a doubt arises and a citizen brings it before this Court for resolution thereof.

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 54 refers to elected members; supports not waiting for all vacancies

arguments.claim: Word 'election' in Art. 71 means entire process culminating in declaration of elected candidate; disputes inquired only after completion

anchor.surface_text: That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institutions, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning. In the narrow sense, it is used to mean the final selection of a candidate which may embrace the result of the poll when there is polling or a particular candidate being returned unopposed when there is no poll. In the wide sense, the word is used to denote the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected.

arguments.claim: Art. 71 analogous to Art. 329(b) and RP Act s.80; disputes only via election petition after entire process per Ponnuswami

anchor.surface_text: Art. 329 provides, amongst other things, that notwithstanding anything in this Constitution no election to either House of Parliament or either House of Legislature of a State shall be called in question except by an election Petition presented to such authority and in such manner as may be provided for by or under any law made by the proper legislature.

arguments.claim: PVPE Act s.14 and s.18 confirm disputes only by election petition to SC after election completed; covers all stages

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 14 of this Act, which corresponds to s. 80 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, no election, meaning the election of the President or Vice-President, shall be called in question except by an election petition presented to this Court in accordance with the provisions of Part III of that Act and of the rules made by this Court under Art.

arguments.claim: Art. 62(1) mandatorily requires Presidential election completed before term expiry; cannot hold up for disputes

anchor.surface_text: Article 62 1 peremptorily requires that the election to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of the President shall be completed before the expiration of the term. It is necessary to bear in mind this clear mandatory provision of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Elections should not be held up; aggrieved person's interest subordinate to public interest in timely elections

anchor.surface_text: The well recognised principle of election law, Indian and English, is that elections should not be held up and that the person aggrieved should not be permitted to ventilate his individual interest in derogation of the general interest of the people, which requires that elections should be gone through according to the time schedule.

arguments.claim: No discrimination under Art. 14; different election dates in constituencies due to local exigencies permissible

holdings.text: the present petitions are premature and cannot be entertained at this stage

anchor.surface_text: We express no opinion on the merits of any of the controversies between the parties, but, for the foregoing reasons, we hold that the present petitions are premature and cannot be entertained at this stage. We, therefore, dismiss the petitions Nos. 63 and 64 of 1957.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 71 requires inquiry into doubts/disputes only after entire election process completes (wide meaning of 'election' per Ponnuswami precedent), confirmed by PVPE Act ss.14,18 and SC rules; complies with mandatory Art.62(1); public interest against holding up elections.

holdings.text: the word election occurring in Art. 71(1) ... the same wide meaning as comprising the entire election process culminating in a candidate being declared elected ... the inquiry is to be made after such completed election

anchor.surface_text: If we give to the word ,election occurring in Art. 71 1  the same wide meaning as comprising the entire election process culminating in a candidate being declared elected, then clearly the inquiry is to be made after such completed election, i.e., after a candidate is declared

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long usage and Ponnuswami decision give 'election' wide meaning covering entire process from nomination to declaration; applies to Art.71 by analogy with Art.329(b), RP Act s.80, PVPE Act ss.14,18.

holdings.text: Art. 71 postulates an election and the word election occurring in Art. 71 means the entire election process culminating in a candidate being declared elected and doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with any of the stages of such completed election have to be inquired into and decided by this Court ... after the completion of the entire process compendiously called the election

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment Art. 71 postulates an election and the word election occurring in Art. 71 means the entire election process culminating in a candidate being declared elected and doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with any of the stages of such completed election

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Art.71 consistent with Parliament's PVPE Act 1952 (ss.14,18), SC rules under Art.145, avoids conflict with Art.62(1) mandatory timing, aligns with election law principle against interlocutory challenges.

holdings.text: Article 62(1) peremptorily requires that the election to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of the President shall be completed before the expiration of the term

anchor.surface_text: Article 62 1  peremptorily requires that the election to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of the President shall be completed before the expiration of the term. It is necessary to bear in mind this clear mandatory provision of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of Art.62(1) imposes mandatory duty to complete election before term ends; informs timing of Art.71 inquiries.

holdings.text: elections should not be held up and ... the person aggrieved should not be permitted to ventilate his individual interest in derogation of the general interest of the people, which requires that elections should be gone through according to the time schedule

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-recognised election law principle (Indian/English) prioritizes timely completion over individual grievances; supports post-election challenge only.

anchor.surface_text: N.P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency  1  the Returning Officer for that companystituency had rejected, the  1   1952  S.C.R. 218.

precedents.case_name: N.P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency
precedents.cited_proposition: The word 'election' has a wide meaning denoting the entire process culminating in a candidate being declared elected, and orders at any stage cannot be challenged except by election petition after completion of the process.
precedents.cited_holding: High Court had no jurisdiction under Art. 226 to interfere with Returning Officer's rejection of nomination; challenge only by election petition under Art. 329(b) and s. 80 RPA after entire election process.

Article 62 1  peremptorily requires that the election to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of the President shall be completed before the expiration of the term. It is necessary to bear in mind this clear mandatory provision of the Constitution.
We, therefore, dismiss the petitions Nos. 63 and 64 of 1957.
